I was always curious about where the POP property is supposed to land in terms of its cultural influences.

It's a western property but obviously draws from Middle Easter and Asian culture. "Persia" in the title obviously means Iran, but Sans of Time is set in the palace of a Maharaja which I think is the title of an Indian monarch. Two Thrones specifically names Babylon as the Prince's home city.

I've only ever played the post-Sands games so I don't know if the history of the franchise goes into greater detail on this.

Completely unrelated, but I'm also curious about this. I was under the assumption (admittedly just from reading Wiki) that Urdu and Hindi are actually just two standardized varieties of the same language, and that Farsi is a completely different language from both of them though part of the same umbrella language family. Or has Urdu just been way more influenced by Farsi over the years due to geographic proximity to Greater Iran?

Edit: I looked up some shit on Reddit that seems to suggest the historical relationship between Farsi and Urdu is kinda like that between French and English.

Hindi developed in India as an offshoot of Sanskrit (a mother language like Latin).

Persian influence created a new language Urdu, when Farsi mixed with Hindi. However, Urdu words have entered into everyday Hindi vocabulary and all Hindi speakers use a smattering of Urdu words, but Urdu and Hindi are different languages with the Hindi writing script based on the Devnagri script (Sanskrit used Devnagri) and Urdu writing script based on Farsi and Arabic. Most Hindi speakers cannot read Urdu.

It's worse. The two main staff members shown in the dev commentary part after the trailer, the director and the producer of this game, only seem to have had experience working on Just Dance before this game according to their MobyGames pages.

On one hand, it's super nice for them that they get to learn by remaking a great game like this, and that this will be their debut as a "main" Ubisoft studio.

On the other hand, it is absolutely correct of the majority of posters in this thread to assume that this is Ubisoft treating Prince of Persia as a little side game, almost like a mobile game. In fact, judging from the games they have made, Ubisoft Pune seems to be a studio that yes, helps for Ubisoft's big games, but has never put out something that they are the main developers for... except mobile games, like the (pretty shitty) Prince of Persia: The Shadow and the Flame remake in 2013. Considering the fact that these people have worked on a few PoP titles already, it's likely that the only reason this remake is happening at all is that there are a few PoP fans at that studio, and not because Ubisoft wanted to make it.

My god what is this awful shit. I had forgotten Ubisoft had also remade POP2 and never checked it out. Why does the Prince look like his Warrior Within self? lol

Well for such a "PoP fan" he clearly missed the plot about the original game taking place in... India, not Persia.

And as we all know there is no way to have any representation of a culture if the game isn't set in that country. Just look at Ghost of Tsushima. They had zero representation of Mongols culture and traditions, right?

It's not like that in the game's story this take place after Persia had conquered India, so it wouldn't be out of place if some Persian artifacts, literature, notes, letters, equipment, etc, were found in the environment.

It's not like Prince could wear a more Persian style clothing.

It's not like Prince himself is supposedly from Persia so it would make perfect sense for him to say some small Farsi sentences whenever he is frustrated that he couldn't make a jump in platforming or messed up in combat.

It's not like Ubisoft mixed up the Arabic and Persian culture so much in the first game that they had Arabic inscriptions on Prince's sword in the original release but now they've taken that out and instead of maybe adding some Farsi inscriptions in there to you know, have a small nod to the fact that Prince is supposed to be from Persia, they've decided to just have no inscriptions at all.

It's not like Ubisoft did a behind the scenes video right after the announcement which they could've used to at least acknowledge the fact that this Prince of Persia game, is gonna have some representations of Persian culture as well, but instead they didn't even mentioned Persia or Persian culture even once outside of saying the title of the game.

Yes, you are absolutely right. The game takes place in India (just the beginning of it, then it goes to the fictional land of Azad) so there was no way for Ubisoft to have any Persian representation. Silly me.
